with that pretty frequently okay so on sort of a the life of an engineer sort of day-to-day at Pinterest working in
your group looks like what generally speaking Yeah so back when I started again the team was was much smaller the
overall ads organization was much smaller so things were moving a lot faster we had less checks in place for
things like we're going to talk about scale and cicd today we didn't have as as robust a system as we did today
people were able to make changes a lot faster however that came at the cost of a lack of proper verification in place

the piece of feedback that was missing was is my change actually going to bring down production or cause any major

present your metrics your experiment your ab results essenti to your team leader your org leader and as long as

then now there's a lot more process not necessarily a bad thing I know process has a pretty negative connotation but
one it means we have way fewer severe incidents at least and that means more people at the org have an understanding

process to get where there's a forum that comes together to review the changes and there's healthy debate

us internally or our partners or advertisers okay I imagine that some

the sort of criteria for that essentially is as long as there's not a significant change to any of the 10 to

change is small or big you're going through the same from a technology standpoint from an automated process standpoint it's the same thing there's
no different way of doing things if it's a small change or different way if it's a big thing that's right okay so with
that said what are sort of the stages right of this pipeline so I'm thinking
generally speaking most people only really have they do their unit test locally and there might be some integration tests that happen you know
in the cloud and maybe there's a a staging environment involved right that's kind of for most people that's
sufficient right so how basically what are the different stages in your pipeline and why do you have all those different stages yeah and I'm happy to
say that this is something that's evolved a lot as we've scaled as well so just backing up again to what I do as part of leading the ad serving platform
team our responsibilities are to enable the ad team to continue to grow and deliver and launch more products new
algorithms to improve ads delivery efficiency on the platform we're over a $2 billion company now that all comes
from ad so that's part of what we do the other side of that obviously is again going back to scale and compliance
making sure that our systems are scaling at a ideally sublinear cost rate so for
every dollar made we don't want to be spending an additional dollar that's one condition and also as the number of
Engineers grows and the number of changes grow in our system we don't want to be having as many or as frequent or as severe outages at the very least so
given that those requirements having a robust cicd system integration testing staging environment Etc incremental roll
out became extremely important so what this was like when I joined Pinterest was I'm proud to say that the ads team
was one of the first teams to have a continuous deployment process so there was pretty good foundation for me to build on top of essentially when you
committed your change within let's say the next 30 minutes it would hit a canary environment that canaran
environment was essentially just let's say one host and the goal of that host was to ensure and this is a ghost
service so the goal of that host was to just make sure that your service is not panicking and crashing if it did it
would trigger an alert to an on caller who would then go in look at the cause for the Panic roll back the change
ensure that it doesn't go out to further stages Etc once it pass that initial Canary test which is about a 10 to 15
minute test it would go out to a what we call this staging with let's say like a larger Canary essentially which was that
point let's say about 1% of the cluster and of the entire production cluster this is all serving production traffic
so now these 1% of the cluster we can actually monitor more application Level metrics whether that is number of ads
inserted CPU usage memory usage dis usage Etc at that point I want to say we were monitoring probably about 70 to 80
metrics if any of those metrics showed a significant regression and we could tune the thresholds for each of those alerts
it would trigger similarly an alert to our team on teams on caller who would have to go in and manually pause deploys
and the whole the whole process of debugging from there on forth what we've evolved a lot since is is we no longer
require the on colar to go manually pause deploys or roll back deploys we have a system in place it's built on top
of Spiner which is an open source platform from Netflix if I remember correctly essentially your CD pipeline
will automatically pause a deploy if any of those metrics show a significant regression so that was a big win because
one to reduce the stress on our on callers two it actually reduce the number of incidents that could have just
prevented by someone going in and clicking the button at the right time besides that what we built in you mentioned ation testing and the fact
that some people you know sometimes will run some local testing then push out their changes and wait for feedback in production we realized that was actually
one really big gap because there was no great way of enforcing that people were actually running that local test because
that essentially required the code reviewer to to follow up and ensure that sufficient testing was performed and again like you said depending on whether
it's a small change or a large change the burden on the reviewer change is based on that as well so we wanted something more uniform that applies to
every single change every single code change runs in a reasonable amount of time doesn't require developers to be
sitting there for an hour while their tests run and gives us reasonable confidence that if this change goes out we're not saying that it's definitely
not going to cause an outage but at least we're not going to have a significant outage that's going to bring down the service bring down the site etc
etc so one thing we built is what we call a presubmit test that was actually one of my first projects when I joined the company essentially every request
that comes into Pinterest we log a sample of that or every request that comes into the ad system rather we log a
certain sample of that to a Kaa topic and then when we want to run this online integration test essentially every time
you put up a new PR we package your changes similar to how we would for a production build package your changes
create an artifact that this presubmit test framework then deploys for you to a couple of test hosts so now that we have
that log traffic we can essentially tail that kofka log get some number of requests send them to these hosts
simulating production traffic without actually affecting any users that host then emits its own set of metrics we can
essentially grab those metrics compare them against a production cluster or at least a different host that is running a
the latest version of of your main branch see if there's any significant regression and obviously we losing the
thresholds for that because we're only running this test for anywhere from like 3 to 10 minutes and if there is a regression then your commit is
essentially blocked from Landing before until you resolve those discrepancies we wanted to make sure and
I think we successfully achieved this that this test is able to run in less than 10 to 15 minutes because one of the
great parts of go in our relatively smaller code base at that point was that it the our entire repository our entire
service at least was able to build an artifact in about I want to say four to five minutes so if we suddenly
introduced this test that ran for 30 minutes developers would have hated us saying you know our developer speed just
went up almost 10x so that was one of the things that we wanted to guarantee that this test essentially ran in 10
minutes you did not need to wait for more than 10 minutes for all your Jenkins builds your unit test to pass
and for this integration test to pass before you were able to land your change those were the two key parts that came
out was this prmit integration testing which allowed us to actually Define which metrics need to be monitored and
then secondly was this automated Canary analysis essentially which is I think an industrywide practice at this point but
that really saved us a lot of lot of headache of manual process and reduced the stress on our on callers and on top
of that we've now seen a lot of teams actually adopting these Frameworks add in their own metrics so for instance I

these metrics are a stable enough B actually protecting our systems similarly with the presubmit test
themselves when we first rolled it out the infro team just configured 10 metrics I think um which were mainly
system performance related now we're up to about 90 metrics added by all sorts of product and quality teams to ensure

the granularity of checking the number of ads inserted for simulated dark users coming from Canada or Japan or something
like that we would obviously have to increase our our sample size to get a meaningful number there but this
framework gives you that that level of flexibility which was widely adopted and has really helped us a lot mhm so it
